comments:
Please see the following mails:

-------------------------------------------



Hi

Some more info about this exception (I'm using Eclipse 3.1.2). 


In CPPSemantics.java, function: getTargetParameterTypes(), Line 2141 is:
	cls = (ICPPClassType)
CPPTemplates.instantiateWithinClassTemplate( (ICPPClassTemplate) cls );


Inside instantiateWithinClassTemplate() method in CPPTemplates.java, control goes to following loop, for certain methods

		if( template instanceof CPPClassTemplate ){
			return ((CPPClassTemplate)template).instantiate(
args );
		} 

And as soon as control returns to CPPSemantics.java, where conversion to ICPPClassType is made, exception is thrown.

If any other info might be required, please let me know.


Regards
Virender.

-----Original Message-----


Hi Folks

For one of my plug-ins, I'm adding some default directories to the list of Includes for the projects. These directories are symbolic links to standard include directories for the compiler that we are using (aCC).
However, if link to one particular directory is added
(/.../aCC/include_std) and then C/C++ Full Indexer is enabled, then I get an exception, which starts as given below. Are there any restrictions on what can be added to Include Paths ? Am I doing something wrong or is it an Eclipse bug ?

Regards
Virender. 


------------------------------------------------------------------------
-----------------

Thanks, I'll take a look for 3.1.1.
You mention you are using Eclipse 3.1.2. Are you really using CDT 3.1? Or was this CDT 3.0.x? If it was CDT 3.1, did you try the Fast indexer?

> You mention you are using Eclipse 3.1.2. Are you really using CDT 3.1? Or was
> this CDT 3.0.x? If it was CDT 3.1, did you try the Fast indexer?


This exception came with Eclipse 3.1.2 and I was using CDT_3_0_2_RC1 plugins. I tried with Eclipse 3.2 + CDT 3.1. No exception shows up in console window (as for CDT 3.0.x). However, it seems that contents of this include (../aCC/include_std) have not been indexed. When I do C/C++ Search for some method declared inside this include directory (say, cout declared in iostream.h), nothing is returned. I get correct search results for some of the other include directories that I checked (say, printf declared in stdio.h).
O.K. since the exception isn't present in 3.1, I'll move this off the 3.1.1 list. The severity is lower and I'm not sure I'll be address it since I don't have an aCC install to try things out with.
